channel.title: The Drafting Table
channel.description: Calm, Clear, and Hand-Crafted Architectural Design

item.title: Journal
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The journal is where we think in public. Here you will find reflections on the design process, observations from site visits, and notes on materials and craft.

item.title: On the Character of Board-Formed Concrete
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There is a particular quality to concrete that has been cast against rough-sawn boards. The grain of the wood transfers to the surface of the wall, leaving a ghost image of the formwork in the hardened material.

We have been experimenting with different board species for our formwork. Douglas fir leaves a bold, pronounced grain. Cedar produces something softer, more subtle.

The Sand Aggregate Question

For the Meadow House, we sourced sand from a local glacial deposit. The aggregate carries a warm, amber undertone that gives the finished concrete the color of the surrounding sandstone bluffs.

The surface of a wall is its face. It should tell you honestly what lies behind it and how it came to be.

Studio notes, January 2025
item.excerpt:encoded: There is a particular quality to concrete that has been cast against rough-sawn boards. The grain of the wood transfers to the surface of the wall.

item.title: The Cantilever as Architectural Gesture
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The cantilever is more than a structural technique. It is a declaration of intent. When a roof extends beyond its supporting wall, it says to the landscape: I am reaching toward you.

Structural Honesty

A cantilever should express its structural logic. The visitor should be able to read the forces at work: the compression in the back span, the tension in the top reinforcement.

The cantilever is the architecture of generosity: the building gives more shelter than it takes ground.

From a lecture, February 2025
item.excerpt:encoded: The cantilever is more than a structural technique. It is a declaration of intent.

item.title: Selecting Copper for the Assembly Hall Roof
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We have been deliberating on the roof material for the Lakeside Assembly Hall for several weeks now. The shortlist came down to three options: standing-seam copper, weathering steel, and zinc.

The Lake Context

The Assembly Hall sits on the shore of Lake Mendota. Against the backdrop of mature oaks and the grey-blue of the lake, a verdigris roof will appear almost natural.
item.excerpt:encoded: We have been deliberating on the roof material for the Lakeside Assembly Hall. Today we committed to copper.

item.title: Drawing by Hand in a Digital Age
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A question we are asked frequently: why do you still draw by hand? The software exists. The efficiency gains are documented. All of this is true, and yet we persist with graphite and vellum.

The Productive Imprecision

A hand drawing is productively imprecise. It suggests rather than specifies. This ambiguity is valuable in the early stages of design because it leaves room for discovery.

The pencil is an extension of the thinking hand. It does not merely record decisions; it participates in making them.

From the drafting table, March 2025
item.excerpt:encoded: A question we are asked frequently: why do you still draw by hand? The reason is not nostalgia.

item.title: Timber Joinery and the Japanese Tradition
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Marcus returned from his research trip to Kyoto last week, and the studio has been in a productive ferment ever since. He brought back detailed sketches of traditional Japanese timber joints.

Adapting the Tradition

We are not proposing to replicate Japanese joinery wholesale. The structural demands of our buildings differ from the Japanese context. But the principle is transferable: that wood can be shaped to hold itself together.
item.excerpt:encoded: Marcus returned from his research trip to Kyoto, and the studio has been in a productive ferment.

item.title: Limestone Walls and the Memory of the Sea
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Visited the Lannon quarry this morning to select stone for the Ridgeline Dwelling foundation walls. The quarry cuts through Silurian dolomite, deposited four hundred million years ago.

Coursing and Character

We will use random-coursed ashlar, which means the stone will be cut to varying heights and laid in irregular horizontal courses.
item.excerpt:encoded: Visited the Lannon quarry this morning to select stone for the Ridgeline Dwelling.

item.title: Glass, Transparency, and the Dissolution of Walls
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The great innovation of modern architecture was the liberation of the wall from its structural obligations. Once the load was carried by a frame, the wall could disappear entirely.

The Frame Within the Frame

Every window is a composition. Its proportions, its mullion pattern, its relationship to the wall in which it sits, all shape what the inhabitant sees.
item.excerpt:encoded: The great innovation of modern architecture was the liberation of the wall from its structural obligations.

item.title: Pseudo-ashlar
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The steps of the Aphrodite temple, rebuilt in the Roman period, reveal an improvisational system of anathyrosis, where a very narrow chisel was used to trim quickly the inner joint faces of the step blocks, and neatly dress the exterior where the blocks meet their (now-missing) neighbors. This pseudo-ashlar system is backed by small fieldstones embedded in mortar as an infilling that would have been concealed by the lost stylobate course above. Acropolis, Amathus.
item.excerpt:encoded: “Tooling” by orientalizing, CC BY-NC-ND 2.0

item.title: Cantilever
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The cantilevered terraces are key to the organization and experience of Fallingwater, uniting the indoor and outdoor space.
